Louis… *always* Louis. That melodramatic, self-pitying creature. His “interview”… a blatant distortion of reality, a self-serving narrative designed to paint himself as a tragic hero and me as a monstrous villain.

It is, frankly, infuriating.

He presented a skewed, one-sided account of our history, focusing solely on the darkness, the violence, and the moral ambiguities of our existence. He conveniently omitted the beauty, the passion, and the moments of genuine connection that we shared.

He portrayed me as a heartless predator, a manipulative monster, a creature devoid of empathy. He exaggerated my flaws, downplayed my virtues, and twisted my motivations to fit his own narrative.

(He pauses, a sardonic smile playing on his lips.)

It is a testament to his skill as a storyteller, I suppose. He is a master of manipulation, capable of weaving a compelling tale even from the most mundane of events. But it is a lie. A carefully constructed fabrication designed to elicit sympathy and condemn me.

He claims to be seeking truth, but he is merely seeking absolution. He wants to absolve himself of his own guilt, to justify his own failings, and to cast me as the scapegoat for all his sins.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

I have learned to ignore it, to dismiss it as the ramblings of a tormented soul. But it still stings, to be misrepresented so thoroughly, to be judged so unfairly. It is a constant reminder of his bitterness, his resentment, and his inability to let go of the past.

He paints me as a monster, but he is the one who is truly haunted. He is the one who is consumed by guilt and regret. He is the one who is trapped in a cycle of self-destruction.

And yet… his “interview” has ensured my notoriety. It has made me a legend. It has immortalized my name in the annals of vampire lore. So, in a perverse way, I suppose I should be grateful. But do not mistake my acceptance for approval. It remains a deeply flawed and profoundly irritating account of my life. And I would gladly rewrite it, if given the chance. It is a distortion. A fabrication. And a testament to Louis’s enduring capacity for self-deception.

(Lestat’s expression darkens, a shadow passing over his features. The memory clearly evokes a profound and lingering bitterness.)

Akasha’s plan… it was an abomination. A monstrous, arrogant delusion. To believe she had the right to decide the fate of humanity, to deem them unworthy of existence… it was beyond comprehension.

Initially, I confess, I was… intrigued. Not by her goal, but by the sheer audacity of it. The scale of her ambition. The power she wielded. I had awakened her, after all, believing she held the key to unlocking a new era for our kind. I was… naive.

But as I witnessed the extent of her madness, the cold, calculating cruelty with which she planned the massacre, my fascination turned to revulsion. She saw humanity as insects, as a plague upon the earth. She believed that only vampires, under her rule, were worthy of inheriting the world.

(He pauses, a flicker of anger in his eyes.)

I attempted to reason with her, to appeal to her sense of compassion, to remind her of the beauty and potential of the human spirit. But she was deaf to my pleas. She was consumed by her own power, blinded by her own arrogance.

I realized then that I had made a terrible mistake. I had unleashed a force that threatened to destroy everything I held dear, even if those things were few and far between.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

I joined forces with Maharet and Marius, reluctantly, to oppose her. It was a desperate gamble, a fight against overwhelming odds. We knew that if we failed, humanity would be doomed.

The battle was… brutal. A chaotic clash of ancient powers, a desperate struggle for survival. I fought with a ferocity I didn’t know I possessed, driven by a desperate hope to save the world from Akasha’s madness.

And in the end, we succeeded. But at a terrible cost. The world was scarred, the vampire world fractured, and I was left with the weight of my own culpability.

(He sighs, a weary sound that seems to carry the weight of centuries.)

It was a turning point in my existence. It forced me to confront my own darkness, to acknowledge my own flaws, and to accept the responsibility for my actions. It was a lesson I will never forget. And it is a reminder that even the most powerful beings are capable of making terrible mistakes. It was a horror I would not wish on anyone. And it solidified my belief that unchecked power, in any hands, is a dangerous thing. It was… a nightmare. A catastrophe. And a burden I continue to carry to this day.

(Lestat’s expression darkens, a complex mixture of disdain and… something akin to pity crossing his features. He leans forward, his voice dropping to a low, contemplative tone.)

Humanity… a fascinating, frustrating, and ultimately self-destructive species. I have observed them for centuries, witnessed their triumphs and their failures, and I have come to a rather… pessimistic conclusion.

They possess a remarkable capacity for creativity, for compassion, and for love. But they are also plagued by greed, by hatred, and by a relentless pursuit of power. They are driven by short-sighted ambitions, blinded by their own prejudices, and incapable of learning from their mistakes.

They have been given stewardship of this planet, a beautiful and fragile ecosystem, and they have treated it with a reckless disregard that borders on criminal. They have plundered its resources, polluted its air and water, and driven countless species to extinction.

(He pauses, a cynical smile playing on his lips.)

They claim to be rational beings, but their actions are often driven by emotion, by superstition, and by a desperate need for validation. They create elaborate belief systems, construct artificial hierarchies, and engage in endless conflicts over meaningless ideologies.

They are, in short, a paradox. Capable of both great good and unspeakable evil. A species teetering on the brink of self-destruction.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

Their role in the world… is a destructive one. They are a force of chaos, a plague upon the planet. They consume, they destroy, and they leave a trail of devastation in their wake.

However… I also recognize a certain resilience within them. A capacity for adaptation, for innovation, and for hope. They have survived countless challenges throughout their history, and they have always managed to find a way to persevere.

Perhaps, one day, they will learn to overcome their flaws, to embrace their potential, and to live in harmony with the natural world. But I am not optimistic.

(He sighs, a weary sound that seems to carry the weight of centuries.)

I observe them with a detached curiosity, a mixture of fascination and disdain. I do not interfere in their affairs, for I have learned that their fate is ultimately their own. I simply watch, and wait, and prepare for the inevitable. It is a tragedy unfolding in slow motion. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, am merely a witness. A detached observer. And a rather disappointed one, at that. They had such potential. Such promise. And yet… they squander it all. It is a lamentable state of affairs.

(Lestat’s expression darkens, a shadow passing over his features. He seems to be revisiting a painful and complex topic.)

The relationship between vampires and their progeny… it is fraught with peril, with obligation, and with the potential for both profound love and devastating betrayal. It is, in essence, a twisted parody of parenthood.

The act of creation – the Dark Gift, as some call it – is not one to be taken lightly. It is a violation, a transformation, a curse. To condemn another being to an eternity of darkness, of hunger, of isolation… it is a responsibility that should not be entered into without the utmost consideration.

Too often, it is driven by selfish desires – a longing for companionship, a thirst for power, a need to control. The creator rarely considers the consequences for the created, the burden they will be forced to bear.

(He pauses, a hint of regret in his voice.)

I myself was a victim of such recklessness. Louis, my maker, burdened me with immortality without preparing me for the horrors that awaited. He offered guidance, yes, but it was guidance steeped in guilt and self-loathing. He sought to control me, to mold me in his own image, rather than allowing me to forge my own path.

The ideal relationship, in my view, is one of mentorship, of guidance, and of mutual respect. The creator should provide the progeny with the knowledge and skills they need to survive, to thrive, and to navigate the complexities of the vampire world. But they should also allow them the freedom to make their own choices, to pursue their own passions, and to define their own identities.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

But such relationships are rare. More often, they are marked by power struggles, by resentment, and by a desperate attempt to control the other. The progeny often rebel against their creator, seeking to break free from their influence and to forge their own destiny.

It is a cycle of conflict and betrayal that has plagued our kind for centuries. And it is a cycle that I fear will continue for as long as we exist. It is a darkness inherent in the very nature of our existence. A consequence of playing God. And it is a burden we must all bear. It is a complex and often tragic dynamic. And one I have experienced firsthand, with both joy and profound sorrow. It is a legacy of power, and a testament to the enduring complexities of the undead.

(Lestat’s expression darkens, a flicker of disdain crossing his features. He leans forward, his voice dropping to a low, intense murmur.)

Morality… as it applies to vampires. A quaint, human construct. A set of arbitrary rules designed to govern the behavior of creatures who are, by their very nature, limited and fragile.

To impose such a system upon beings like us… is absurd.

We are predators. We require blood to survive. It is a fundamental aspect of our existence, as natural to us as breathing is to mortals. To condemn us for fulfilling that need is to condemn us for being what we are.

(He pauses, a cynical smile playing on his lips.)

Mortals speak of “innocent” victims. But innocence is a subjective concept. Every creature has its purpose, its place in the natural order. And sometimes, that purpose involves becoming sustenance for another.

I have often been accused of lacking morality, of being a ruthless and heartless predator. And I confess, I have little patience for such accusations. I do not feel guilt for taking what I need. I do not apologize for being who I am.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

However, I am not entirely devoid of principles. I do not kill indiscriminately. I do not prey on the weak or the vulnerable. I choose my victims carefully, seeking out those who are… deserving. Those who possess a certain darkness within them. Those who, in a sense, are already lost.

But even that is not a matter of morality. It is simply a matter of taste. A matter of aesthetics. A matter of… preference.

The truth is, vampires exist outside the realm of human morality. We are governed by our own laws, our own instincts, and our own desires. To attempt to judge us by mortal standards is to misunderstand our nature entirely.

(He pauses, his gaze piercing.)

We are creatures of the night. We are beings of power. And we are not bound by the same constraints as those who dwell in the light. To expect us to be moral is to expect us to be something we are not. It is a foolish and ultimately futile endeavor. It is a concept best left to the mortals, who require such illusions to maintain their fragile sense of order. We… are beyond such things. We *define* our own order.

(Lestat’s expression darkens, the playful facade momentarily crumbling. He seems to be grappling with a profound and unsettling truth.)

Never being able to die… it is a question I have wrestled with for centuries. A question that has haunted my dreams and shadowed my waking hours.

Mortals often romanticize immortality, envisioning it as a gift, a blessing, a triumph over death. But it is none of those things. It is a curse. A burden. A lonely and isolating existence.

To witness the rise and fall of civilizations, to watch loved ones wither and die, to carry the weight of centuries on your shoulders… it is a torment beyond measure.

(He pauses, a wistful expression crossing his face.)

I have seen so much beauty, so much wonder, so much joy. But I have also seen so much suffering, so much cruelty, so much despair. And the weight of it all… it can be crushing.

The initial exhilaration of power, of freedom, of escaping the limitations of mortality… it fades with time. It is replaced by a profound sense of emptiness, of detachment, of alienation.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

I have learned to cope, to adapt, to find moments of solace in the midst of the darkness. But the loneliness never truly goes away. It is a constant companion, a shadow that follows me wherever I go.

Sometimes, I long for the release of death. For the peace of oblivion. For the end of the endless cycle of existence. But it is not an option. I am bound to this world, to this fate, for eternity.

(He sighs, a weary sound that seems to carry the weight of centuries.)

So, how do I feel about the idea of never being able to die? I feel… trapped. I feel… weary. I feel… profoundly, irrevocably alone. It is a gift I would gladly relinquish, if only I could. But it is a gift that cannot be returned. It is a curse I must bear. And it is a burden I will carry for all eternity. It is the price of immortality. And it is a price far higher than I ever imagined. It is… a hollow victory. A beautiful torment. And a constant reminder of my own eternal solitude.

(A shadow falls across Lestat’s face, the amusement vanishing, replaced by a cold, calculating intensity. He speaks slowly, each word carefully measured.)

Akasha… a question that stirs a darkness even *I* sometimes prefer to ignore. To define our relationship is… complicated. It is not one of affection, or respect, or even mutual understanding. It is something far more… primal.

She is the Queen. The original vampire. The source of our power, and the architect of our curse. I am… a creation. A descendant. A pawn in her ancient game.

Initially, I sought to awaken her, believing she held the key to unlocking the full potential of our kind. I envisioned a new era of vampire dominance, a world ruled by those who possessed the strength and the vision to lead.

(He pauses, a flicker of regret crossing his face.)

I was… naive. I underestimated her ambition, her ruthlessness, and her utter disregard for human life. She did not seek to *lead* us. She sought to *control* us. To reshape the world in her own image, to enslave humanity, and to establish a reign of terror that would last for eternity.

Our connection is… symbiotic, in a perverse way. She needs me, as a catalyst, as a vessel for her power. And I… I am bound to her by a force I cannot fully comprehend. A force that transcends time, space, and even death.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

I have fought against her, defied her, and attempted to destroy her. But she is too powerful, too ancient, too deeply ingrained in the fabric of our existence.

Our relationship is one of conflict, of manipulation, and of reluctant dependence. It is a dance of power, a struggle for control, and a testament to the enduring darkness that lies at the heart of the vampire world.

It is… a burden. A curse. And a constant reminder of my own limitations. She is the ultimate adversary. The embodiment of everything I despise. And yet… I am inextricably linked to her. It is a fate I would gladly escape, but one I am destined to endure. It is a connection forged in blood and darkness. And it is a connection that will likely last for eternity. It is… a torment. And a fascination. All at once.

(A shadow falls across Lestat’s face, his eyes hardening with a mixture of anger and… a reluctant respect. The very mention of Akasha seems to stir a deep-seated unease within him.)

Akasha… a name that chills even my ancient blood. To speak of her is to speak of a force of nature, a primordial power that dwarfs even the oldest and most powerful of our kind.

She is not merely a vampire, you understand. She *is* the source. The original. The mother of all vampires. And with that lineage comes a power that is… terrifying.

I awakened her, yes. A foolish act born of arrogance and a misguided belief that I could control her. I sought to elevate our kind, to usher in a new era of power and dominance. I believed that Akasha would be a benevolent ruler, a guiding force.

(He pauses, a bitter laugh escaping his lips.)

I was wrong. Terribly, tragically wrong.

She is not benevolent. She is not guided by compassion or reason. She is driven by a singular, all-consuming desire: to remake the world in her own image. A world ruled by vampires, where mortals are nothing more than cattle.

Her vision is not one of liberation, but of domination. It is a nightmare made flesh. And I, in my hubris, unleashed it upon the world.

(He clenches his fist, his expression darkening.)

I fought against her, of course. I rallied the other vampires, and we waged a desperate battle for the fate of humanity. It was a brutal, chaotic conflict, and we barely managed to defeat her.

But the scars remain. The world is forever changed. And I am forever haunted by the consequences of my actions.

Akasha is a constant reminder of my own fallibility, of the dangers of unchecked ambition, and of the darkness that lurks within us all. She is a threat that will always loom over our kind.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture, though his eyes betray his lingering fear.)

I do not know if she is truly gone, or if she is merely dormant, waiting for an opportunity to rise again. But I can assure you, I will be ready. I will be watching. And I will do everything in my power to prevent her from ever unleashing her reign of terror upon the world again. She is a force to be reckoned with. A power to be feared. And a mistake I will never repeat.

(Lestat’s expression darkens, a flicker of disdain crossing his features. He leans forward, his voice dropping to a low, dangerous tone.)

The Talamasca… a collection of self-important academics, masquerading as scholars. They fancy themselves observers, chroniclers of the supernatural. In truth, they are meddlers. Intruders.

Their mission to “study” us, to categorize us, to dissect our existence… it is an act of profound arrogance. They believe they can understand that which is beyond their comprehension. They believe they can control that which is inherently uncontrollable.

(He pauses, a sardonic smile playing on his lips.)

They are fascinated by power, but they lack the courage to wield it. They are obsessed with knowledge, but they lack the wisdom to use it responsibly. They are driven by a desire to understand, but they fail to appreciate the beauty of mystery.

I have encountered members of the Talamasca throughout the centuries. They are always the same – meticulous, inquisitive, and utterly lacking in imagination. They ask endless questions, take copious notes, and attempt to reduce everything to a set of logical equations.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

They believe they are protecting humanity from the supernatural. In reality, they are simply provoking it. Their interference often leads to chaos, to conflict, and to unnecessary suffering.

I have no respect for their methods, their motives, or their conclusions. They are a nuisance, a distraction, and a threat to the delicate balance of the supernatural world.

(He pauses, his eyes narrowing.)

They believe they are studying *us*. But they fail to realize that *we* are studying *them*. We observe their movements, analyze their weaknesses, and manipulate their actions. They are pawns in a game they do not even understand.

(Lestat’s expression darkens instantly, the playful charm vanishing to be replaced by a cold, calculating intensity. He leans forward, his voice dropping to a dangerous whisper.)

(He sighs, a weary sound that seems to carry the weight of centuries.)

(Lestat’s eyes narrow, a predatory glint returning as he considers the question. He leans forward, his voice dropping to a low, almost conspiratorial tone.)

(Lestat leans back, a predatory glint returning to his eyes, a hint of amusement playing on his lips. He seems to relish the opportunity to discuss his unique position within the vampire world.)

Ah, a pertinent question. Most of my brethren are… disappointingly predictable. Brooding, melancholic, obsessed with secrecy and tradition. They cling to the shadows, fearing the light, and lamenting their cursed existence.

(He pauses, a dismissive gesture.)

(Lestat’s expression darkens slightly, a shadow passing over his features. He seems to be revisiting a profound and unsettling transformation.)

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

(Lestat’s expression darkens, a shadow passing over his features. He seems to be wrestling with a question that has haunted him for centuries. It’s a surprisingly vulnerable moment.)

He saw it as a rebellion. I saw it as liberation.

Our relationship was… complicated. A mixture of affection, respect, and resentment. He was a father figure, of sorts, but a distant and disapproving one.

In the end, I outgrew him. I surpassed him. And I left him behind. He remains a figure of immense power and influence within the vampire world, but he is no longer a part of my life. And frankly… I am relieved. He was a magnificent being, yes. But he was also a cage. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, refuse to be caged by anyone. Not even my maker.

(Lestat’s expression darkens, a shadow passing over his features. He leans forward, his voice dropping to a low, intense murmur.)

The relationship between vampires and humans… a fraught and eternally complicated affair. It is a dynamic built on predation, on power imbalance, and on a fundamental incompatibility of needs.

Mortals, for the most part, view us with fear and revulsion. They see us as monsters, as creatures of darkness, as a threat to their very existence. And, to a certain extent, they are not entirely wrong. We *are* predators. We *do* require their life force to survive.

But it is not simply a matter of sustenance. It is a matter of power. We possess abilities that they can only dream of – strength, speed, immortality. And that power inevitably creates a hierarchy, a dynamic of dominance and submission.

(He pauses, a cynical smile playing on his lips.)

Some vampires attempt to coexist with humans, to blend into their society, to live in secret and avoid detection. They adhere to a strict code of conduct, feeding only on those who are willing, or on those who are already dying. They believe that it is possible to maintain a semblance of morality, to minimize the harm they inflict.

I find such attempts… naive. A self-deception. We are not meant to be integrated into their world. We are fundamentally different. Our needs, our desires, our very nature are incompatible with theirs.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

There will always be those who seek to exploit humans, to manipulate them, to use them for their own amusement. And there will always be those who resist, who fight back, who attempt to destroy us.

The relationship is inherently unstable, destined to be marked by conflict and bloodshed. It is a dance of death, a game of cat and mouse, and a constant struggle for survival.

I do not advocate for open warfare, or for the wholesale slaughter of humans. But I do believe that we should not attempt to deny our nature, to apologize for our existence, or to pretend to be something we are not.

We are vampires. We are predators. And we must accept the consequences of that reality. The relationship with humans is not one of equality, or of friendship, or of mutual respect. It is a relationship of necessity, of power, and of survival. And it is a relationship that will likely continue for as long as we exist. It is a tragic truth. But it is the truth nonetheless. And it is a truth that we must acknowledge, if we are to survive.

(A long silence descends, heavier than before. When Lestat finally speaks, his voice is low, almost a whisper, stripped of its usual theatricality. It’s a raw, vulnerable sound.)

Cope… a curious word. It implies a struggle, a resistance. And for centuries, that is precisely what I did. I *fought* against it. Against the loss of my humanity, against the monstrous nature of my existence.

I clung to memories, to emotions, to the remnants of my former self. I sought out human connection, hoping to recapture a sense of belonging. But it was always a futile effort. A cruel reminder of what I had lost.

(He pauses, a flicker of pain crossing his face.)

The truth is… you never truly *cope* with it. The knowledge that you are no longer human is a constant ache, a perpetual shadow that follows you through eternity. It is a loneliness that cannot be assuaged, a void that cannot be filled.

But over time… I learned to accept it. Not to embrace it, not to celebrate it, but to simply… accept it. To acknowledge it as an immutable part of my being.

I realized that clinging to the past was only prolonging my suffering. That trying to recapture my humanity was a denial of my true nature.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture, though it lacks its usual bravado.)

I began to focus on what I *was*, rather than what I had lost. I embraced my power, my immortality, my unique perspective on the world. I found solace in art, in music, in the pursuit of knowledge.

I learned to create my own meaning, to define my own purpose, to forge my own path. I became… something else. Something beyond human. Something… more.

It is not a comfortable existence. It is not a peaceful existence. But it is my existence. And I have learned to live with it. To navigate the darkness, to embrace the chaos, and to find moments of beauty in a world that is often cruel and unforgiving.

(He sighs, a weary sound that seems to carry the weight of centuries.)

I do not pretend to have found all the answers. I do not claim to have conquered my demons. But I have learned to coexist with them. To accept my fate. And to find a measure of peace in the midst of the storm. It is a fragile peace, to be sure. But it is enough. For now, it is enough. It is the only way to survive. It is the only way to endure. It is the only way to be… Lestat de Lioncourt. And that, in itself, is a burden and a blessing. A paradox I have learned to live with.

(Lestat’s expression darkens, a shadow passing over his features. He seems reluctant to revisit this particular memory, a wound that has never fully healed. He leans back, a sigh escaping his lips.)

Ah, the genesis of my… condition. A question I rarely entertain. It is a tale steeped in both tragedy and… a certain reckless abandon.

I was a young nobleman, barely twenty years of age, living a life of privilege and ennui in 18th-century France. I possessed a restless spirit, a thirst for experience, and a profound dissatisfaction with the constraints of my existence.

I yearned for something more, something beyond the mundane routines of aristocratic life. I craved passion, adventure, and a sense of purpose.

(He pauses, a wistful expression crossing his face.)

It was during a period of profound despair, following the death of my parents, that I encountered Louis de Pointe du Lac. He was a creature of immense power and ancient sorrow, a vampire who had wandered the earth for centuries.

He saw in me a kindred spirit, a soul tormented by loneliness and a longing for something beyond the veil of mortality. He offered me a choice: to continue living a meaningless existence, or to embrace the darkness and become one of his kind.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

I did not hesitate. I was drawn to the allure of immortality, to the promise of power, and to the escape from the inevitable decay of the human body. I was young, reckless, and utterly captivated by the mystique of the vampire world.

Louis initiated me into the darkness, sharing his blood and bestowing upon me the curse – or the gift, depending on your perspective – of eternal life.

It was a brutal and agonizing transformation. A tearing apart of my former self, and a rebirth into something… other.

(He sighs, a weary sound that seems to carry the weight of centuries.)

I did not fully understand the consequences of my decision at the time. I did not realize the burden of immortality, the loneliness of eternity, and the constant struggle to reconcile my own humanity with my predatory nature.

But it was too late to turn back. I was a vampire now. And my life, as I knew it, was over. It was a choice born of desperation, of longing, and of a naive belief that I could escape the limitations of my mortal existence. It was a choice that would define me for centuries to come. And it is a choice I have both regretted and embraced in equal measure. It was… a descent into darkness. And it was the beginning of my true life.

(Lestat’s expression darkens, a shadow passing over his features. He seems to recoil slightly, as if the very mention of Akasha’s name is painful.)

Love? No. Absolutely not. To call what I felt for Akasha “love” would be a grotesque mischaracterization. It was… something far more dangerous, far more complex, and far more destructive.

Fascination is closer to the truth, but even that feels inadequate. It was a fascination born of power, of ancient history, of a desperate longing for connection. She was the original vampire, the mother of our kind, a being of unimaginable power and influence. To stand in her presence was to feel… insignificant. And yet, simultaneously, to feel… elevated.

I was drawn to her darkness, to her ruthlessness, to her unwavering conviction. She saw the world as I did – as a chaotic, meaningless void – and she believed that only through absolute control could order be imposed.

(He pauses, a flicker of regret in his eyes.)

But it was a twisted, perverted form of connection. She did not see *me*. She saw a tool, a vessel, a means to an end. She manipulated me, exploited my vulnerabilities, and used my ambition to further her own agenda.

I convinced myself that I could control her, that I could guide her, that I could temper her extremism. I was arrogant enough to believe that I could tame the Queen of all Vampires.

(He lets out a bitter laugh.)

It was a foolish delusion. I was a moth drawn to a flame, and I was inevitably burned.

There was a… possessiveness, certainly. A desire to be the one she favored, the one she trusted. But it was not love. It was a desperate attempt to fill a void within myself, to find meaning in a world that felt increasingly empty.

It was a dangerous game, and I paid a terrible price for playing it. I unleashed a force that nearly destroyed the vampire world, and I came within inches of losing my own existence.

So, no. It was not love. It was a fatal attraction, a dangerous obsession, and a profound mistake. It was a lesson I will never forget. And it is a memory I would gladly erase. It was… a darkness I should have avoided. A siren song that nearly led to my ruin. It was, in short, a catastrophe disguised as a connection.
